contents.title: Variables in JavaScript
contents.content:
Variables are containers for storing data values. JavaScript has three ways to declare variables:

1. var (old way - avoid using):
   â€¢ Function-scoped
   â€¢ Can be redeclared
   â€¢ Hoisted to top
   â€¢ Can cause bugs

2. let (modern way):
   â€¢ Block-scoped
   â€¢ Cannot be redeclared in same scope
   â€¢ Not hoisted
   â€¢ Use when value will change

3. const (modern way):
   â€¢ Block-scoped
   â€¢ Cannot be reassigned
   â€¢ Must be initialized
   â€¢ Use by default

Best Practices:
â€¢ Use const by default
â€¢ Use let only when you need to reassign
â€¢ Never use var in modern JavaScript
â€¢ Use descriptive variable names
â€¢ Follow camelCase naming convention

contents.title: Variable Declaration Examples

examples.title: Variable Scope
examples.explanation: let and const are block-scoped, meaning they only exist within the block {} they are defined in. Global variables are accessible everywhere.

examples.title: Variable Naming Best Practices
examples.explanation: Use descriptive names that explain what the variable stores. Use camelCase for regular variables and UPPERCASE for constants.
